info.name: Arc APIs Postman Collection
info.description:
A collection of API requests for Arc Publishing that's useful for content management or content migrations.

# Setup
In order to properly setup this question you must first:

1. Import the collection
2. Create a new environment
3. Add the following environment variables
 - **baseUrl** - *[ENV]*.*[ORG-NAME]*.arcpublishing.com
 - **token** - an access token generated from your Developer Center. *NOTE: An admin token is required for POST/PUT requests.*
 - **website** - the multisite website ID that you want to run these API commands for
 - **search_key** - the key for your provisioned Arc search, this is provided by your TAM or TDM
4. Save your changes
5. Select your environment from the Postman dropdown box
6. Identify the API endpoint you want to use, click on it
7. In the tab that opens, modify the *Query* and *Path* variables to suit your needs
8. Modify the *Body* section to add/edit/delete the proper information (if applicable)

request.description:
Publishes the `Document`'s current draft `Revision` by creating a clone of the current draft `Revision` and setting it as the `Document`'s published `Revision`. A new clone of the current draft `Revision` is also created.

This API returns the new published `Revision`.
Unpublishes the published `Revision` for the specified `Document`.
Retrieves all `Revisions` that belong to the `Document` specified by `type` and `id`.
Retrieves the specified `Revision` that belongs to the `Document` specified by `type` and `id`.

Creates a new draft `Revision` from the request body Revision and sets it as the specified `Document`'s draft `Revision`.

This API returns the new draft `Revision`.

This endpoint will reject any object received in input if the following fields are set:

  - ans.websites
  - ans.canonical_url
  - ans.taxonomy.sections
  - ans.taxonomy.sites
  - ans.taxonomy.primary_section
  - ans.taxonomy.primary_site

ANS > `0.10` is required.

Creates a new draft `Revision` from the current published `Revision` for the `Document` specified by `type` and `id`.  This operation does not affect the current published `Revision`.

This API returns the new draft `Revision`.

query.description: Query parameter to allow an auto-incremented URL over a failure condition in case of URL collision.

request.description:
Creates or updates a `Circulation`. The `website_url` field may be omitted to trigger (re)generation based on pre-configured formatting rules.

If the `website_url` value changes, a new `Redirect` is created to forward from the old value to the new. If the new value of `website_url` matches an existing `Redirect`, the existing `Redirect` is converted to the `Circulation`'s primary URL.
Deletes the `Circulation`  of the given `Document` for a website.
Retrieves a `Circulation` for a given `Document` and website.

query.description: Pagination cursor returned in `last` field from a previous response

request.description: Retrieves a paginated list of `Circulation` objects for the given document. If the result length is too long, Draft API may return a `last` pagination cursor to supply in `after` parameter with a subsequent call for the next page.
Retrieves the `Document` specified by `type` and `id`.

query.description: Website ID from Site Service
Pagination cursor returned in `last` field from a previous response

request.description: Retrieves a paginated list of `Redirect` objects for the given `Document`.  The returned `Redirects` can be a `Document Redirect` or an `External Redirect` that resolves to the `Document`.  If the result length is too long, Draft API may return a `last` pagination cursor to supply in `after` parameter with a subsequent call for the next page.  Results are sorted by `updated_at` in descending order.

response.name: Array of `Redirects`

request.description:
Creates a new `Document` of the specified `type`.  An ANS document (> `0.10`) must be specified in the HTTP body which will be used draft `Revision`.

This endpoint will reject any object received in input if the following fields are set.
  - websites
  - canonical_url
  - taxonomy.sections
  - taxonomy.sites
  - taxonomy.primary_section
  - taxonomy.primary_site

query.description: Website ID from Site Service

variable.description: Relative URL served by the Arc Platform

request.description: Fetches a `Redirect` resolving `website_url` on the given website.  `Redirect` can be a `Document Redirect` or an `External Redirect`

query.description: Website ID from Site Service

variable.description: Relative URL served by the Arc Platform

request.description: Updates a `Redirect`. Either `redirect_to` or `document_id` must be supplied for the target URL. The `redirect_to` field specifies a redirection rule pointing at an arbitrary URL (aka an External Redirect). `document_id` defines a redirect that always points to a `Document`'s current Circulation URL (aka a Document Redirect).

query.description: Website ID from Site Service

variable.description: Relative URL served by the Arc Platform

request.description: Creates a `Redirect`. Either `redirect_to` or `document_id` must be supplied for the target URL. The `redirect_to` field specifies a redirection rule pointing at an arbitrary URL (aka an External Redirect). `document_id` defines a redirect that always points to a `Document`'s current Circulation URL (aka a Document Redirect).

query.description: Website ID from Site Service

variable.description: Relative URL served by the Arc Platform

request.description: Unsets a redirect resolving `url` on the given website.

query.description: Pagination cursor returned in `last` field from a previous response

request.description: Lists URL Format Rules for the given website. A pagination cursor may be returned in the `last` for fetching subsequent pages via the `after` parameter.

query.description: Website ID from Site Service

request.description: Creates a new URL Format Rule from a given formatting expression. The request accepts a Unique ID for a given website. If not present in the request JSON, a unique value will be set automatically. Can be `default`.

response.name: Bad Request

request.description: Deletes an URL Format Rule on the given website

The tolerance, between 0 and 442, for trimming

How to fit into a space, either `normal` `full` or `adaptive`
The horizontal alignment of the crop, either `left` `center` or `right`
The vertical alignment of the crop, either `top` `middle` or `bottom`
If the crop should be smart (finding focal points) or not
The desired width of the image
The desired height of the image
The brightness, between -100 and 100
The contrast, , between -100 and 100
A colorize parameter, of the form `red:green:blue:fill`, each of -100 to 100
If the color distribution of the image should be equalized
The color to fill in empty parts of the iamge
Return in a new format, either `webp`, `jpeg`, `gif`, or `png`
If the image should be gray-scaled
Automatically degrades the quality of the image until it is no larger than this
Adds noise to an image, between 0 and 100
Do not upscale the image to bigger dimensions
The overall quality of a JPEG, between 0 and 100
Changes the color of the image, in the form r:g:b, each between -100 and 100
Round the corners with a color background, of form `radius:background`
Rotate the image in degrees, either 0 90 180 or 270
Scales the saturation of the image between 0 and 100
Remove any ICC information from the image
Watermark the image, of form `url::horiz position::vert position::transparency`
Add Gaussian blur, of the form `radius[:sigma]`
Sharpen the image, in the form `amount:radius:luminance`

Returns the current configuration of fields in your Author Service. New fields can be added and some fields can be hidden by making a change request with the Arc Platform team.

response.name: Get configuration
response.body:
{
    "q_results": [
        {
            "_id": "58e67900d30886000e125168",
            "key": "firstName",
            "label": "First Name",
            "type": "text",
            "placeholder": "first name",
            "versionUpdated": 2

item.description: The first version of the Authors API which includes a configuration endpoint you can use to create new fields in the Authors Service interface.

A collection of API calls for working with the Author service. Use this to perform specific CRUD operations on your site's Authors.

Documentation is available at: https://redirector.arcpublishing.com/alc/docs/swagger/?url=./arc-products/authors.json

item.name: Pagebuilder API

query.description: The website to look up content for. If empty, this will be appended automatically by the public origin
Elastic search query
GraphQL filter

variable.description: The content source you want to fetch content from

request.description: Fetch a specific piece of content, using the content source and query specified. Optionally filter the content with a provided graphql filter.

query.description: The website to look up content for. If empty, this will be appended automatically by the public origin
Elastic search query

request.description: Resolve a query into the upstream url used to fetch content. This endpoint is used for debugging fetch requests.

query.description: The website to look up content for. If empty, this will be appended automatically by the public origin
Elastic search query

request.description: Clear the cache of a specific piece of content, using the content source and query specified.

query.description: The website to look up content for. If empty, this will be appended automatically by the public origin
Elastic search query

request.description: Update the cache for a specific piece of content, using the content source and query specified.

query.description: The output type to render

request.description:
Render the specified page/rendering/template/chain/feature by id as HTML. If generating a page/rendering/template, the result will be wrapped in the appropriate output-type (either as specified, or the default) and is suitable as a complete webpage. If generating a chain/feature, the containing page/rendering/template must be specified, and the resultant HTML will be only the chain/feature requested, with no output-type wrapping. A page/rendering/template may be rendered without an output-type wrapping by specifying outputType=false.

To render with global content, use a POST request where the body of the request contains a JSON object with top-level content property. The body may also contain the id (and will take precedence over the URI).

Resolve the trailing URI segment into a piece of global content and an associated page/template.
Resolve the trailing URI segment into a piece of global content and an associated page/template, then render the content into the template and return the resultant HTML.

item.name: assets

variable.description: the output type to get the javascript for

request.description:
This returns the javascript function that is used by the fusion engine to generate a rendering. It is used by the client-side browser to update the template, if necessary, as well as hydrate script functionality in the browser.

Pages and Templates should be referenced by id so that you will always receive the current published version. If you need an unpublished script, you must request it by rendering id.

If a request for a page/template is not found in S3, it will be generated on-demand, returned to the caller, and pushed to S3.

variable.description: The output type to return these scripts for

Return static files as found in your bundle's /resources directory.
This is the primary client-side library that is shared and used for all pages/templates. It is specific to a fusion release, and can be cached very aggressively.

item.description: Assets are read significantly more frequently than they are written, so they will be stored in and served statically from S3.

All endpoints described below will be handled as displayed by the lambda function. However, the lambda functions will be exposed publicly at /pf/api/v3, so each endpoint must be prefixed to be accessed.

All requests that begin with /pf/dist or /pf/resources will be handled as if prefixed with /pf/api/v3/dist. All other requests that do not begin with /pf/api/v3 will be handled as /pf/api/v3/make/:request_uri.

Documentation is also available at: https://redirector.arcpublishing.com/alc/arc-products/pagebuilder/fusion/documentation/api/http/API.md?version=2.4

request.description: To run this locally please see the README at https://github.com/washingtonpost/ans-schema. Otherwise paste your JSON into the body of the request and you will recieve true if this is valid for our ANS schema or an error message. Make sure your ans_version matches the ans_version in the body you are sending.

query.description: The tag you want to search for

item.name: Story API (Deprecated)
{edition}

request.description: Get the the specified edition of a story

response.name: Get a Story Edition

request.description: Publish the provided revision of a story to the specified edition. Returns all the revisions that this edition has pointed to and the timestamps of when they were set/unset. The history of edition values is presented in chronological order as a JSON array.  If an item in this list does not have a revision property, it should be considered to be an "unpublish" (DELETE) action. Otherwise, it should be considered to be a "publish" (PUT) action. All dates are presented for all actions as stored in the database.

response.name: History for a Story Edition
response.body:
[
  {
    "_id":"C3RED6ISKVGSVA3TWQ7Z5LG5AI",
    "last_updated_date":"2016-06-15T15:16:42.141Z",
    "headlines":{"basic":"Test Greg Foo"},
    "revision": { 
      "revision_id":"NSYHFE7JMNA5THLONLJ4U77GFU",
      "parent_id":"6ZLRO4YQ5RAIRHS5YR545CRSUY",
      "branch":"default"
    },
    "type":"story",
    "edition_date":"2016-06-15T15:17:43.497Z",
    "publish_date":"2016-06-15T15:17:43.497Z",
    "display_date":"2016-06-15T15:17:43.497Z"
  },
  {
    "_id":"C3RED6ISKVGSVA3TWQ7Z5LG5AI",
    "last_updated_date":"2016-06-15T15:14:27.813Z",
    "headlines":{"basic":"Test Greg Foo"},
    "type":"story",
    "edition_date":"2016-06-15T15:21:25.868Z",

  }

    "headlines": {"basic":"Test Greg Foo"},
    "revision": {
      "revision_id":"NSYHFE7JMNA5THLONLJ4U77GFU",
      "parent_id":"6ZLRO4YQ5RAIRHS5YR545CRSUY",
      "branch":"default"
    },
    "type":"story",
    "edition_date":"2016-06-15T15:18:00.314Z",
    "publish_date":"2016-06-15T15:18:00.314Z",
    "display_date":"2016-06-15T15:17:43.497Z"
  }

request.description:
Publish the provided revision of a story to the specified edition.

`revision_id` is required. The unique revision id to publish.

`publish_date` is the RFC3339-formatted timestamp when this edition is considered to have been published. (This will populate in the story object only on requests to retrieve this edition).

`display_date` is the RFC3339-formatted timestamp when this story is considered to have been published. (This will populate in the story object only on requests to retrieve this edition).

response.name: Publish a Story Edition

request.description: Unpublish the specified edition

item.description:
Get a story's editions.

Dates in Edition Request/Responses

`last_updated_date` is the date that the revision was created (api-generated - users cannot change this)

`edition_date` is the date that the edition was created (api-generated - users cannot change this)

`publish_date` is the date that the particular edition should be considered to have been created (set in the "Publish an edition" endpoint). This should mainly be used if you are importing data from legacy systems and want to preserve real publish timestamps for logging purposes.  If not set, it will default to be the same as edition_date.

`display_date` is the date that should display to end-users (set in the "Publish an edition" endppoint). If not set, it will default to the previous edition_date in the history sequence. (For the first edition, it will default to publish_date.)

request.description:
Create a new revision of a story, saving the provided content to a new revision in branch "default", or on the specified branch.

The story `_id` and `revision.parent_id` **must be included**, and revision.revision_id **must be omitted**. The `_id` on individual content elements may also be omitted.

Note that when a caller PUTs a document to the server, `revision.parent_id` should be set to the value of `revision.revision_id` of the most recent version of the document on the branch being updated, and `revision.revision_id` should be empty.  In practice, this means clients you should GET a story, make any desired changes to the local copy, then perform something like this before PUTing the edited document back:

```
story.revision.parent_id = story.revision.revision_id;
delete story.revision.revision_id;
```

response.name: Create A Revision

query.description: If present, return this revision of the story. Optional. Cannot be used if branch also present.
The branch name

request.description: Publishes a specific revision as a specific edition. Body of the request must include revision_id, published_date and display_date. Dates must be in RFC3339-formatted timestamps (these will populate in the story object only on requests to retrieve this edition).

response.name: Publish an Edition

request.description: Remove a published edition of a story

The history of edition values is presented in chronological order as a JSON array.  If an item in this list does not have a revision property, it should be considered to be an "unpublish" (DELETE) action.  Otherwise, it should be considered to be a "publish" (PUT) action.  All dates are presented for all actions as stored in the database.

request.description:
This endpoint gets a list of stories.  If neither id nor revision_id are specified, then it will return stories up to limit in reverse chronological order, based on last update time of the latest revision on the default branch for each story. If id is specified, you may also use the branch or edition parameter to determine which revision/edition of each story is returned. 

Specify multiple ids like so:

?id=ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ&id=ZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA&id=AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

response.name: Get a List of Stories

request.description:
When creating a new story, the story _id and revision should be omitted.  The _id on individual content elements may also be omitted.

This endpoint supports automatic publishling  see the description under the PUT /story/:id endpoint.

See https://github.com/washingtonpost/ans-schema/blob/master/src/main/resources/schema/ans/0.5.8/story.json for more details.

response.name: Create a Story

request.description:
The story API handles batch requests by processing a number of atomic operations on individual stories simultaneously, optimizing internally. 

## Support
The following RESTful operations from the /api/v2/story endpoint can be included in a batch request:

* DELETE /api/v2/story/:id
* PUT /api/v2/story/:id
* POST /api/v2/story
* PUT /api/v2/story/:id/edition/:edition
* DELETE /api/v2/story/:id/edition/:edition

## Limitations
The same story object may not be operated on more than once in the same batch request.  Such requests will immediately fail. E.g., the same batch request may not include both of the following:

* PUT /api/v2/story/4B2NVBFMWVBB3B4OJ74JN6WU64
* DELETE /api/v2/story/4B2NVBFMWVBB3B4OJ74JN6WU64

No more than 100 individual request items may be included in a single batch request.

## Update and Publish
The API does not support separate update+publish objects in the same request, but it does support the Story API v2 combined update and publish request.

Each item object should use the following format:

```
{
	method: <string:"PUT" | "DELETE" | "POST">,
	url: <string:"ie. api/v2/story">,
	story: <object:"ANS story object (optional)">,
	edition: <object:"ANS story edition"
}
```

* Method and url are combined to resolve the request item as if an individual HTTP request had been made.
* Story object is required for POST /api/v2/story and PUT /api/v2/story/:id
* A story edition request object. Required for PUT /api/v2/story/:id/edition/:edition.
